Secured by basic

logicalSwitchPortGroupFix /backing post

Resolving Missing Port Groups for a Logical Switch

post

For every logical switch created, NSX creates a corresponding port group in vCenter. If the port group is missing, the logical switch will stop functioning.

If the port group backing a logical switch is deleted, you can recreate a new backing port group for the logical switch.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.2.3Method introduced.

post logicalSwitchPortGroupFix /2.0/vdn/virtualwires/{virtualWireID}/backing

For every logical switch created, NSX creates a corresponding port group in vCenter. If the port group is missing, the logical switch will stop functioning.

If the port group backing a logical switch is deleted, you can recreate a new backing port group for the logical switch.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.2.3Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • virtualWireID: required (string)

    A logical switch id, e.g. virtualwire-1002

Query Parameters

  • action: required (string)

    • remediate: The remediate action performs the resync action and then creates a new backing port group for the logical switch. Under normal operations, you should need the remediate action only.

    • resync: The resync action removes the association between the backing port group and the logical switch in the NSX Manager configuration.

Secured by basic

logicalSwitchConnCheck /conn-check/multicast post

Testing Host Connectivity

post

Test multicast group connectivity.

Test multicast group connectivity between two hosts connected to the specified logical switch.

Parameter packetSizeMode has one of the following values:

  • 0 - VXLAN standard packet size
  • 1 - minimum packet size
  • 2 - customized packet size. If you set packetSizeMode to 2, you must specify the size using the packetSize parameter.

post logicalSwitchConnCheck /2.0/vdn/virtualwires/{virtualWireID}/conn-check/multicast

Test multicast group connectivity.

Test multicast group connectivity between two hosts connected to the specified logical switch.

Parameter packetSizeMode has one of the following values:

  • 0 - VXLAN standard packet size
  • 1 - minimum packet size
  • 2 - customized packet size. If you set packetSizeMode to 2, you must specify the size using the packetSize parameter.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • virtualWireID: required (string)

    A logical switch id, e.g. virtualwire-1002

Body

Type: application/xml

Schema:

<xs:schema attributeFormDefault="unqualified" elementFormDefault="qualified" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">
  <xs:element name="testParameters">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="gateway"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="packetSizeMode"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="packetSize"/>
        <xs:element name="sourceHost">
          <xs:complexType>
            <xs:sequence>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="hostId"/>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="switchId"/>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="vlanId"/>
            </xs:sequence>
          </xs:complexType>
        </xs:element>
        <xs:element name="destinationHost">
          <xs:complexType>
            <xs:sequence>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="hostId"/>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="switchId"/>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="vlanId"/>
            </xs:sequence>
          </xs:complexType>
        </xs:element>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>
</xs:schema>

Example:

<testParameters>
  <gateway></gateway>
  <packetSizeMode></packetSizeMode>
  <packetSize></packetSize>
  <sourceHost>
    <hostId></hostId>
    <switchId></switchId>
    <vlanId></vlanId>
  </sourceHost>
  <destinationHost>
    <hostId></hostId>
    <switchId></switchId>
    <vlanId></vlanId>
  </destinationHost>
</testParameters>

Secured by basic

logicalSwitchHardwareGatewayBinding /{hardwareGatewayBindingId} post

Working With Connections Between Hardware Gateways and Logical Switches

post

Manage the connection between a hardware gateway and a logical switch.

Attach a hardware gateway to a logical switch and create a new binding with the information provided

POST /api/2.0/vdn/virtualwires/{virtualwireid}/hardwaregateways

<hardwareGatewayBinding>
  <hardwareGatewayId>hardwarewgateway1</hardwareGatewayId>
  <vlan>v1</vlan>
  <switchName>s1</switchName>
  <portName>s1</portName>
</hardwareGatewayBinding>

Attach a hardware gateway to a logical switch, specifying an existing binding by ID

POST /api/2.0/vdn/virtualwires/<virtualwireId>/hardwaregateways/{bindingId}?action=attach

<virtualWire>
  ...
  <hardwareGatewayBindings>
    <hardwareGatewayBinding>
      <id>binding id</id>
    </hardwareGatewayBinding>
  </hardwareGatewayBindings>
</virtualWire>

Detach a hardware gateway from a logical switch

POST /api/2.0/vdn/virtualwires/<virtualwireId>/hardwaregateways/{bindingId}?action=detach

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.2.3Method introduced.

  <hardwareGatewayId>hardwarewgateway1</hardwareGatewayId>

  <portName>s1</portName>

  • Security

  • virtualWireID: required (string)

    A logical switch id, e.g. virtualwire-1002

  • hardwareGatewayBindingId: required (string)

    Hardware Gateway Binding ID.

Query Parameters

  • action: (string)

    Specify attach to attach a hardware gateway to a logical switch.

    Specify detach to detach a hardware gateway from a logical switch.

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<hardwareGatewayBinding>
  <hardwareGatewayId>hardwarewgateway1</hardwareGatewayId>
  <vlan>v1</vlan>
  <switchName>s1</switchName>
  <portName>s1</portName>
</hardwareGatewayBinding>

Secured by basic

arpMAC

Working With IP Discovery and MAC Learning for Logical Switches

You can enable IP discovery (ARP suppression) and MAC learning for logical switches or dvPortGroup. Enabling MAC learning builds a VLAN - MAC pair learning table on each vNic.

This table is stored as part of the dvfilter data. During vMotion, dvfilter saves/restores the table at the new location. The switch then issues RARPs for all the VLAN - MAC entries in the table.

Enabling this feature avoids possible traffic loss during vMotion in the following cases:

  • the vNic is in VLAN trunk mode
  • the VM is using more than one unicast MAC address. Since Etherswitch supports only one unicast MAC per vNic, RARP is not processed.

When a logical switch is created using the API, IP discovery is enabled, and MAC learning is disabled.

In cross-vCenter NSX, the following applies:

  • The MAC learning setting for a universal logical switch is managed on the primary NSX Manager. Any changes are synchronized to all secondary NSX Managers.
  • The IP discovery setting for a universal logical switch is managed separately on each NSX Manager.

Note: In NSX 6.2.2 and earlier you cannot disable IP discovery for universal logical switches on secondary NSX Managers.

arpMAC /2.0/xvs/networks/{ID}/features get put

get

Retrieve IP discovery and MAC learning information.

put

Enable or disable IP discovery and MAC learning.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.2.3Method updated. IP discovery can be disabled on secondary NSX Managers.

get arpMAC /2.0/xvs/networks/{ID}/features

Retrieve IP discovery and MAC learning information.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • ID: required (string)

    dvPortGroup MOID or logical switch (virtual wire) ID.

Secured by basic

put arpMAC /2.0/xvs/networks/{ID}/features

Enable or disable IP discovery and MAC learning.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.2.3Method updated. IP discovery can be disabled on secondary NSX Managers.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • ID: required (string)

    dvPortGroup MOID or logical switch (virtual wire) ID.

Body

Type: application/xml

Schema:

<xs:schema attributeFormDefault="unqualified" elementFormDefault="qualified" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">
  <xs:element name="networkFeatureConfig">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element name="ipDiscoveryConfig">
          <xs:complexType>
            <xs:sequence>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="enabled"/>
            </xs:sequence>
          </xs:complexType>
        </xs:element>
        <xs:element name="macLearningConfig">
          <xs:complexType>
            <xs:sequence>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="enabled"/>
            </xs:sequence>
          </xs:complexType>
        </xs:element>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>
</xs:schema>

Example:

<networkFeatureConfig>
  <ipDiscoveryConfig>
    <enabled></enabled>
  </ipDiscoveryConfig>
  <macLearningConfig>
    <enabled></enabled>
  </macLearningConfig>
</networkFeatureConfig>

Secured by basic

nsxControllers

Working With NSX Controllers

For the unicast or hybrid control plane mode, you must add an NSX controller to manage overlay transport and provide East-West routing. The controller optimizes virtual machine broadcast (ARP only) traffic, and the learning is stored on the host and the controller.

nsxControllers /2.0/vdn/controller post get

post

Add a new NSX Controller on the specified cluster. The hostId parameter is optional. The resourcePoolId can be either the clusterId or resourcePoolId.

The IP address of the controller node will be allocated from the specified IP pool.

Note: Controller nodes are deployed with 4 GB of memory regardless of which deployType value is provided.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.3.3Method updated. deployType is no longer required.
get

Retrieves details and runtime status for all controllers. Runtime status can be one of the following:

  • Deploying - Controller is being deployed and the procedure has not completed yet.
  • Removing - Controller is being removed and the procedure has not completed yet.
  • Running - Controller has been deployed and can respond to API invocation.
  • Unknown - Controller has been deployed but fails to respond to API invocation.

When a controller is in Running status, the diskLatencyAlertDetected parameter in the API response shows whether disk latency alert is detected in the controller. This parameter can take one of the following values:

  • True - Disk latency alert is detected in the controller.
  • False - Disk latency is not detected in the controller.
  • Unknown - After the controller connects with the NSX Manager, the NSX Manager receives the disk latency report of the controller after a delay of 30 seconds.

post nsxControllers /2.0/vdn/controller

Add a new NSX Controller on the specified cluster. The hostId parameter is optional. The resourcePoolId can be either the clusterId or resourcePoolId.

The IP address of the controller node will be allocated from the specified IP pool.

Note: Controller nodes are deployed with 4 GB of memory regardless of which deployType value is provided.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.3.3Method updated. deployType is no longer required.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

Body

Type: application/xml

Schema:

<xs:schema attributeFormDefault="unqualified" elementFormDefault="qualified" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">
  <xs:element name="controllerSpec">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="name"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="description"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="ipPoolId"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="resourcePoolId"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="hostId"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="datastoreId"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="deployType"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="networkId"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="password"/>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>
</xs:schema>

Example:

<controllerSpec>
  <name>nsx-controller-node1</name>
  <description>nsx-controller</description>
  <ipPoolId>ipPool-1</ipPoolId>
  <resourcePoolId>domain-c1</resourcePoolId>
  <hostId>host-1</hostId>
  <datastoreId>datastore-1</datastoreId>
  <deployType>medium</deployType>
  <networkId>dvportgroup-1</networkId>
  <password>MyTestPassword</password>
</controllerSpec>

Secured by basic

get nsxControllers /2.0/vdn/controller

Retrieves details and runtime status for all controllers. Runtime status can be one of the following:

  • Deploying - Controller is being deployed and the procedure has not completed yet.
  • Removing - Controller is being removed and the procedure has not completed yet.
  • Running - Controller has been deployed and can respond to API invocation.
  • Unknown - Controller has been deployed but fails to respond to API invocation.

When a controller is in Running status, the diskLatencyAlertDetected parameter in the API response shows whether disk latency alert is detected in the controller. This parameter can take one of the following values:

  • True - Disk latency alert is detected in the controller.
  • False - Disk latency is not detected in the controller.
  • Unknown - After the controller connects with the NSX Manager, the NSX Manager receives the disk latency report of the controller after a delay of 30 seconds.
Secured by basic
  • Response
  • Security

HTTP status code 200

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<controllers>
  <controller>
    <id></id>
    <name></name>
    <description></description>
    <ipAddress></ipAddress>
    <status></status>
    <diskLatencyAlertDetected></diskLatencyAlertDetected>
  </controller>
</controllers>

Secured by basic

get nsxControllerUpgradeAvailability /2.0/vdn/controller/upgrade-available

Secured by basic
  • Security

Secured by basic

nsxControllerJob /progress/{jobId} get

Retrieves status of controller creation or removal, or controller cluster upgrade.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Response
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • jobId: required (string)

    Specified job Id

HTTP status code 200

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<controllerDeploymentInfo>
  <vmId></vmId>
  <progress></progress>
  <status></status>
  <exceptionMessage></exceptionMessage>
</controllerDeploymentInfo>

Secured by basic

nsxController /{controllerId} delete post put

Working With a Specific Controller

delete

Delete the NSX controller.

post

If you power off or delete a controller from vCenter, NSX Manager detects the change in controller status. You can remediate the controller, which will power on a powered off controller, or remove the controller from the NSX Manager database if the controller is deleted.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.2.3Method introduced.
put

Update the name of the controller. The name must not contain spaces or underscores.

When you update the controller name, the following changes are made:

  • the name displayed in the Networking & Security UI is changed to newName
  • the VM name is vSphere is changed to newName-NSX-<controller_id>
  • the VM's hostname is changed to newName-NSX-<controller_id>

Note: The VM hostname is used in controller log entries. If you change the controller hostname, the log entries display the new hostname.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.

delete nsxController /2.0/vdn/controller/{controllerId}

Delete the NSX controller.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • controllerId: required (string)

    Specified controller ID.

    Retrieve available controller IDs with GET /api/2.0/vdn/controller.

    In a cross-vCenter NSX environment, retrieve the controller IDs from the primary NSX Manager.

Query Parameters

  • forceRemoval: required (boolean)

    Specify whether to force removal of controller. Must be set to true to remove last controller of the controller cluster.

Secured by basic

post nsxController /2.0/vdn/controller/{controllerId}

If you power off or delete a controller from vCenter, NSX Manager detects the change in controller status. You can remediate the controller, which will power on a powered off controller, or remove the controller from the NSX Manager database if the controller is deleted.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.2.3Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • controllerId: required (string)

    Specified controller ID.

    Retrieve available controller IDs with GET /api/2.0/vdn/controller.

    In a cross-vCenter NSX environment, retrieve the controller IDs from the primary NSX Manager.

Query Parameters

  • action: required (string)

    Specify remediate to recover from controller shutdown or deletion.

Secured by basic

put nsxController /2.0/vdn/controller/{controllerId}

Update the name of the controller. The name must not contain spaces or underscores.

When you update the controller name, the following changes are made:

  • the name displayed in the Networking & Security UI is changed to newName
  • the VM name is vSphere is changed to newName-NSX-<controller_id>
  • the VM's hostname is changed to newName-NSX-<controller_id>

Note: The VM hostname is used in controller log entries. If you change the controller hostname, the log entries display the new hostname.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • controllerId: required (string)

    Specified controller ID.

    Retrieve available controller IDs with GET /api/2.0/vdn/controller.

    In a cross-vCenter NSX environment, retrieve the controller IDs from the primary NSX Manager.

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<controller>
  <name>newName</name>
</controller>

Secured by basic

nsxControllerStats /systemStats get

Working With NSX Controller System Statistics

get

Retrieve NSX Controller system statistics.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.2.3Method introduced.

get nsxControllerStats /2.0/vdn/controller/{controllerId}/systemStats

Retrieve NSX Controller system statistics.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.2.3Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Response
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • controllerId: required (string)

    Specified controller ID.

    Retrieve available controller IDs with GET /api/2.0/vdn/controller.

    In a cross-vCenter NSX environment, retrieve the controller IDs from the primary NSX Manager.

HTTP status code 200

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<controllerNodeStatus>
  <id>controller-2</id>
  <ipAddress>192.168.110.32</ipAddress>
  <syncTime>1490991545530</syncTime>
  <cpuCoreCount>2</cpuCoreCount>
  <cpuLoadInfo>
    <interval>1</interval>
    <averageLoad>0.17</averageLoad>
  </cpuLoadInfo>
  <cpuLoadInfo>
    <interval>5</interval>
    <averageLoad>0.6</averageLoad>
  </cpuLoadInfo>
  <cpuLoadInfo>
    <interval>15</interval>
    <averageLoad>0.4</averageLoad>
  </cpuLoadInfo>
  <totalMemory>1924280</totalMemory>
  <usedMemory>1542524</usedMemory>
  <cachedMemory>589196</cachedMemory>
  <totalSwap>4190204</totalSwap>
  <usedSwap>0</usedSwap>
  <systemTime>1490991545521</systemTime>
  <upTime>433880</upTime>
  <nodeFailoverReady>false</nodeFailoverReady>
  <nodeDiskLatencyStatus>
    <deviceName>sda</deviceName>
    <refreshTime>1490991404000</refreshTime>
    <latencyType>w_await</latencyType>
    <lastLatency>97.0</lastLatency>
    <avgLatency>28.572</avgLatency>
    <alertEnabled>false</alertEnabled>
  </nodeDiskLatencyStatus>
  <nodeDiskLatencyStatus>
    <deviceName>sda</deviceName>
    <refreshTime>1490991186000</refreshTime>
    <latencyType>r_await</latencyType>
    <lastLatency>9.18</lastLatency>
    <avgLatency>0.0</avgLatency>
    <alertEnabled>false</alertEnabled>
  </nodeDiskLatencyStatus>
  <nodeDiskLatencyStatus>
    <deviceName>dm-1</deviceName>
    <refreshTime>1490991185000</refreshTime>
    <latencyType>w_await</latencyType>
    <lastLatency>0.0</lastLatency>
    <avgLatency>0.0</avgLatency>
    <alertEnabled>false</alertEnabled>
  </nodeDiskLatencyStatus>
  <nodeDiskLatencyStatus>
    <deviceName>dm-1</deviceName>
    <refreshTime>1490991185000</refreshTime>
    <latencyType>r_await</latencyType>
    <lastLatency>51.51</lastLatency>
    <avgLatency>0.0</avgLatency>
    <alertEnabled>false</alertEnabled>
  </nodeDiskLatencyStatus>
  <nodeDiskLatencyStatus>
    <deviceName>dm-0</deviceName>
    <refreshTime>1490991404000</refreshTime>
    <latencyType>w_await</latencyType>
    <lastLatency>129.33</lastLatency>
    <avgLatency>34.16</avgLatency>
    <alertEnabled>false</alertEnabled>
  </nodeDiskLatencyStatus>
  <nodeDiskLatencyStatus>
    <deviceName>dm-0</deviceName>
    <refreshTime>1490991225000</refreshTime>
    <latencyType>r_await</latencyType>
    <lastLatency>0.0</lastLatency>
    <avgLatency>12.678</avgLatency>
    <alertEnabled>false</alertEnabled>
  </nodeDiskLatencyStatus>
</controllerNodeStatus>

Secured by basic

nsxControllerLogs /techsupportlogs get

Working With Controller Tech Support Logs

get

Retrieve controller logs. Response content type is application/octet-stream and response header is filename. This streams a fairly large bundle back (possibly hundreds of MB).

get nsxControllerLogs /2.0/vdn/controller/{controllerId}/techsupportlogs

Retrieve controller logs. Response content type is application/octet-stream and response header is filename. This streams a fairly large bundle back (possibly hundreds of MB).

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • controllerId: required (string)

    Specified controller ID.

    Retrieve available controller IDs with GET /api/2.0/vdn/controller.

    In a cross-vCenter NSX environment, retrieve the controller IDs from the primary NSX Manager.

Headers

  • Content-type: required (string)

    application/octet-stream

Secured by basic

nsxControllerSyslog /syslog post get delete

Working With Controller Syslog Configuration

post

Add controller syslog exporter on the controller.

Deprecated: Starting in 6.4.2, POST/DELETE /api/2.0/vdn/controller/{controllerId}/syslog are deprecated.

Use GET/PUT /api/2.0/vdn/controller/cluster/syslog instead.

Using both these methods is not supported and might result in an inconsistent state on the controller nodes.

get

Retrieve details about the syslog exporter on the controller.

Deprecated: Starting in 6.4.2, POST/DELETE /api/2.0/vdn/controller/{controllerId}/syslog are deprecated.

Use GET/PUT /api/2.0/vdn/controller/cluster/syslog instead.

Using both these methods is not supported and might result in an inconsistent state on the controller nodes.

delete

Deletes syslog exporter on the specified controller node.

Deprecated: Starting in 6.4.2, POST/DELETE /api/2.0/vdn/controller/{controllerId}/syslog are deprecated.

Use GET/PUT /api/2.0/vdn/controller/cluster/syslog instead.

Using both these methods is not supported and might result in an inconsistent state on the controller nodes.

post nsxControllerSyslog /2.0/vdn/controller/{controllerId}/syslog

Add controller syslog exporter on the controller.

Deprecated: Starting in 6.4.2, POST/DELETE /api/2.0/vdn/controller/{controllerId}/syslog are deprecated.

Use GET/PUT /api/2.0/vdn/controller/cluster/syslog instead.

Using both these methods is not supported and might result in an inconsistent state on the controller nodes.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • controllerId: required (string)

    Specified controller ID.

    Retrieve available controller IDs with GET /api/2.0/vdn/controller.

    In a cross-vCenter NSX environment, retrieve the controller IDs from the primary NSX Manager.

Body

Type: application/xml

Schema:

<xs:schema attributeFormDefault="unqualified" elementFormDefault="qualified" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">
  <xs:element name="controllerSyslogServer">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="syslogServer"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="port"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="protocol"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="level"/>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>
</xs:schema>

Example:

<controllerSyslogServer>
  <syslogServer></syslogServer>
  <port></port>
  <protocol></protocol>
  <level></level>
</controllerSyslogServer>

Secured by basic

Use GET/PUT /api/2.0/vdn/controller/cluster/syslog instead.

nsxControllerClusterNtp /ntp get put

Working With Controller Cluster NTP Settings

You can configure up to five NTP servers on the NSX Controller cluster. You can specify NTP servers by IPv4 address or FQDN. If an FQDN is used, DNS settings must also be configured. The same NTP settings are applied to all controller nodes in the cluster.

get

Retrieve NTP configuration for the NSX Controller cluster.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.
put

Update NTP configuration for the NSX Controller cluster.

If the settings fail to apply to one or more controller nodes, an error message is returned. Check the controller node status, and retry the request.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.

get nsxControllerClusterNtp /2.0/vdn/controller/cluster/ntp

Retrieve NTP configuration for the NSX Controller cluster.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Response
  • Security

HTTP status code 200

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<ControllerClusterNtpServers>
  <ntpServers>
    <string>192.168.110.10</string>
    <string>192.168.110.11</string>
  </ntpServers>
</ControllerClusterNtpServers>

Secured by basic

put nsxControllerClusterNtp /2.0/vdn/controller/cluster/ntp

Update NTP configuration for the NSX Controller cluster.

If the settings fail to apply to one or more controller nodes, an error message is returned. Check the controller node status, and retry the request.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<ControllerClusterNtpServers>
  <ntpServers>
    <string>192.168.110.10</string>
    <string>192.168.110.11</string>
    <string>ntp-1.example.com</string>
  </ntpServers>
</ControllerClusterNtpServers>

Secured by basic

nsxControllerClusterDns /dns get put

Working With Controller Cluster DNS Settings

When you configure DNS on the NSX Controller cluster, the same settings are applied to all nodes in the cluster.

Controller cluster DNS settings override any DNS settings configured on the controller IP pool.

DNS Parameters

ParameterDescriptionComments
dnsServerDNS server IP addressRequired. Specify up to 3. Valid input: IPv4 addresses.
dnsSuffixDNS suffix for search orderOptional. Specify up to 3. Valid input: domain name suffix. At least one dnsServer must be configured.
get

Retrieve DNS settings for the NSX Controller cluster.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.2Method introduced.
put

Update DNS settings for all nodes in the NSX Controller cluster.

Note: If the settings fail to apply to one or more controller nodes, an error message is returned. Check the controller node status, and retry the request.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.2Method introduced.

get nsxControllerClusterDns /2.0/vdn/controller/cluster/dns

Retrieve DNS settings for the NSX Controller cluster.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.2Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Response
  • Security

HTTP status code 200

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<ControllerClusterDns>
  <dnsServer>10.1.140.1</dnsServer>
  <dnsServer>10.1.150.1</dnsServer>
  <dnsSuffix>example.com</dnsSuffix>
  <dnsSuffix>dns1.example.com</dnsSuffix>
</ControllerClusterDns>

Secured by basic

put nsxControllerClusterDns /2.0/vdn/controller/cluster/dns

Update DNS settings for all nodes in the NSX Controller cluster.

Note: If the settings fail to apply to one or more controller nodes, an error message is returned. Check the controller node status, and retry the request.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.2Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<ControllerClusterDns>
  <dnsServer>10.1.140.1</dnsServer>
  <dnsServer>10.1.150.1</dnsServer>
  <dnsServer>10.1.160.1</dnsServer>
  <dnsSuffix>example.com</dnsSuffix>
  <dnsSuffix>dns1.example.com</dnsSuffix>
  <dnsSuffix>dns2.example.com</dnsSuffix>
</ControllerClusterDns>

Secured by basic

nsxControllerClusterSyslog /syslog get put

Working With Controller Cluster Syslog Configuration

When you configure syslog on the NSX Controller cluster, the same settings are applied to all nodes in the cluster.

Syslog Parameters

ParameterDescriptionComments
syslogServerSyslog server addressRequired. Specify up to 10. Valid input: IPv4 addresses or FQDN. If FQDN is used, DNS must also be configured.
portSyslog exporter portOptional. Default is 6514. Valid ports: 1-65535.
levelSyslog logging levelOptional. Default is INFO. Valid values: INFO, ERROR, WARN.
protocolSyslog protocolOptional. Default is TLS. Valid values: TLS, UDP, TCP.
certificateCertificateRequired if protocol is set to TLS. Valid value: X.509 PEM encoded certificate.
get

Retrieve syslog settings for the NSX Controller cluster.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.2Method introduced.
put

Update syslog settings for all nodes in the NSX Controller cluster.

If the settings fail to apply to one or more controller nodes, an error message is returned. Check the controller node status, and retry the request.

Important: You can also configure syslog on an individual controller node with the deprecated API POST/DELETE /api/2.0/vdn/controller/{controllerId}/syslog. Using both these methods is not supported and might result in an inconsistent state on the controller nodes.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.2Method introduced.

get nsxControllerClusterSyslog /2.0/vdn/controller/cluster/syslog

Retrieve syslog settings for the NSX Controller cluster.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.2Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Response
  • Security

HTTP status code 200

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<ControllerSyslogServerList>
  <controllerSyslogServer>
    <syslogServer>syslog1.com</syslogServer>
    <port>6514</port>
    <protocol>TLS</protocol>
    <level>ERROR</level>
    <certificate>-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIICWjCCAcMCAgGlMA0GCSqGSIb3DQEBBAUAMHUxCzAJBgNVBAYTAlVTMRgwFgYDVQQKEw ...
-----END CERTIFICATE-----</certificate>
  </controllerSyslogServer>
  <controllerSyslogServer>
    <syslogServer>syslog5.com</syslogServer>
    <port>514</port>
    <protocol>UDP</protocol>
    <level>INFO</level>
  </controllerSyslogServer>
</ControllerSyslogServerList>

Secured by basic

put nsxControllerClusterSyslog /2.0/vdn/controller/cluster/syslog

Update syslog settings for all nodes in the NSX Controller cluster.

If the settings fail to apply to one or more controller nodes, an error message is returned. Check the controller node status, and retry the request.

Important: You can also configure syslog on an individual controller node with the deprecated API POST/DELETE /api/2.0/vdn/controller/{controllerId}/syslog. Using both these methods is not supported and might result in an inconsistent state on the controller nodes.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.2Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<ControllerSyslogServerList>
  <controllerSyslogServer>
    <syslogServer>syslog1.com</syslogServer>
    <port>6514</port>
    <protocol>TLS</protocol>
    <level>ERROR</level>
    <certificate>-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIICWjCCAcMCAgGlMA0GCSqGSIb3DQEBBAUAMHUxCzAJBgNVBAYTAlVTMRgwFgYDVQQKEw ...
-----END CERTIFICATE-----</certificate>
  </controllerSyslogServer>
  <controllerSyslogServer>
    <syslogServer>syslog5.com</syslogServer>
    <port>514</port>
    <protocol>UDP</protocol>
    <level>INFO</level>
  </controllerSyslogServer>
</ControllerSyslogServerList>

Secured by basic

nsxControllerClusterUpgrade /upgrade post

Working With Controller Cluster Upgrade

post

Start the upgrade of the NSX Controller cluster. The upgrade is performed on one controller node at a time.

Before you start the controller upgrade, use GET /api/2.0/vdn/controller to ensure that all three controllers have status of RUNNING. It can take about 10 minutes after the NSX Manager upgrade and reboot for the controllers to reestablish connectivity to the NSX Manager.

This request returns a jobId, for example, jobdata-22307. You can use GET /api/2.0/vdn/controller/progress/{jobId} to get the status of the NSX Controller cluster upgrade.

post nsxControllerClusterUpgrade /2.0/vdn/controller/cluster/upgrade

Start the upgrade of the NSX Controller cluster. The upgrade is performed on one controller node at a time.

Before you start the controller upgrade, use GET /api/2.0/vdn/controller to ensure that all three controllers have status of RUNNING. It can take about 10 minutes after the NSX Manager upgrade and reboot for the controllers to reestablish connectivity to the NSX Manager.

This request returns a jobId, for example, jobdata-22307. You can use GET /api/2.0/vdn/controller/progress/{jobId} to get the status of the NSX Controller cluster upgrade.

Secured by basic
  • Security

Secured by basic

nsxControllerPassword /credential put

Working With the NSX Controller Password

put

Change the NSX controller password.

put nsxControllerPassword /2.0/vdn/controller/credential

Change the NSX controller password.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

Body

Type: application/xml

Schema:

<xs:schema attributeFormDefault="unqualified" elementFormDefault="qualified" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">
  <xs:element name="controllerCredential">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="apiPassword"/>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>
</xs:schema>

Example:

<controllerCredential>
  <apiPassword></apiPassword>
</controllerCredential>

Secured by basic

nsxControllerSync /synchronize put

Working With Controller Synchronization

You can resynchronize the NSX Controller cluster with NSX Manager. You might want to do this if you notice that the controller cluster has extra, stale, or missing configuration items.

put

Synchronize the controller cluster with the NSX Manager database.

put nsxControllerSync /2.0/vdn/controller/synchronize

Synchronize the controller cluster with the NSX Manager database.

Secured by basic
  • Security

Secured by basic

nsxControllerSyncStatus /status get

Working with Controller Synchronization Status

Retrieve the status of the controller synchronization.

get

Get the status of the controller synchronization.

If the sync is in progress, the response includes the status JOB_IN_PROGRESS, and the jobId. If the sync has finished, the response includes the status NOT_RUNNING.

get nsxControllerSyncStatus /2.0/vdn/controller/synchronize/status

Get the status of the controller synchronization.

If the sync is in progress, the response includes the status JOB_IN_PROGRESS, and the jobId. If the sync has finished, the response includes the status NOT_RUNNING.

Secured by basic
  • Response
  • Security

HTTP status code 200

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<controllerSyncStatus>
  <status>JOB_IN_PROGRESS</status>
  <jobId>jobdata-201</jobId>
</controllerSyncStatus>

Secured by basic

hostsHealth

Working With Hypervisor Tunnel Health Status Using BFD

Provides overall information about tunnel health of hypervisor. Tunnel, pNIC, control plane, and management plane statuses are displayed.

hostsHealthStatus /status get

Working with overall information about tunnel health of a hypervisor

get

Retrieve overall information about tunnel health of a hypervisor.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.

get hostsHealthStatus /2.0/vdn/host/status

Retrieve overall information about tunnel health of a hypervisor.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

Query Parameters

  • source: (string)

    Specify source as REALTIME, or CACHED. Default value is CACHED. Use status?source=REALTIME to get current status. Use status?source=CACHED to get cached status.

  • status: (string)

    Specify UP, DOWN, DEGRADED to filter by status. Default value is NONE.

  • host_id: (string)

    Specify host ID.

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<hostStatus>
  <hostId>host-23</hostId>
  <status>UP</status>
  <controlConnectionStatus>UP</controlConnectionStatus>
  <mgmtConnectionStatus>UP</mgmtConnectionStatus>
  <pnicStatus>
    <status>UP</status>
    <upCount>1</upCount>
    <downCount>0</downCount>
    <degradedCount>0</degradedCount>
  </pnicStatus>
  <tunnelStatus>
    <status>UP</status>
    <upCount>1</upCount>
    <downCount>0</downCount>
    <degradedCount>0</degradedCount>
    <bfdStatusCount>
      <bfdAdminDownCount>0</bfdAdminDownCount>
      <bfdUpCount>3</bfdUpCount>
      <bfdDownCount>0</bfdDownCount>
      <bfdInitCount>3</bfdInitCount>
    </bfdStatusCount>
    <bfdDiagnostic>
      <echoFunctionFailedCount>0</echoFunctionFailedCount>
      <noDiagnosticCount>1</noDiagnosticCount>
      <pathDownCount>0</pathDownCount>
      <administrativelyDownCount>0</administrativelyDownCount>
      <controlDetectionTimeExpiredCount>0</controlDetectionTimeExpiredCount>
      <forwardingPlaneResetCount>0</forwardingPlaneResetCount>
      <reverseConcatenatedPathDownCount>0</reverseConcatenatedPathDownCount>
      <neighborSignaledSessionDownCount>0</neighborSignaledSessionDownCount>
      <concatenatedPathDownCount>0</concatenatedPathDownCount>
    </bfdDiagnostic>
  </tunnelStatus>
</hostStatus>

Secured by basic

hostIdHealthStatus /{hostId}/status get

Working with tunnel health status for a specific host

get

Retrieve information about tunnel health status for a specific host. NSX Manager obtains tunnel status from the host periodically and updates the cache. When the source is specified as realtime, the current status of the tunnel is retrieved. In the meantime, NSX Manager updates the tunnel status in the cache. When the source is specified as cached, the tunnel status is retrieved directly from the cache.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.

get hostIdHealthStatus /2.0/vdn/host/{hostId}/status

Retrieve information about tunnel health status for a specific host. NSX Manager obtains tunnel status from the host periodically and updates the cache. When the source is specified as realtime, the current status of the tunnel is retrieved. In the meantime, NSX Manager updates the tunnel status in the cache. When the source is specified as cached, the tunnel status is retrieved directly from the cache.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • hostId: required (string)

    ID of the host.

Query Parameters

  • source: (string)

    Specify source as REALTIME, or CACHED. Default value is CACHED. Use status?source=REALTIME to get current status. Use status?source=CACHED to get cached status.

  • status: (string)

    Specify UP, DOWN, DEGRADED to filter by status. Default value is NONE.

  • host_id: (string)

    Specify host ID.

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<hostStatus>
  <hostId>host-23</hostId>
  <status>UP</status>
  <controlConnectionStatus>UP</controlConnectionStatus>
  <mgmtConnectionStatus>UP</mgmtConnectionStatus>
  <pnicStatus>
    <status>UP</status>
    <upCount>1</upCount>
    <downCount>0</downCount>
    <degradedCount>0</degradedCount>
  </pnicStatus>
  <tunnelStatus>
    <status>UP</status>
    <upCount>1</upCount>
    <downCount>0</downCount>
    <degradedCount>0</degradedCount>
    <bfdStatusCount>
      <bfdAdminDownCount>0</bfdAdminDownCount>
      <bfdUpCount>3</bfdUpCount>
      <bfdDownCount>0</bfdDownCount>
      <bfdInitCount>3</bfdInitCount>
    </bfdStatusCount>
    <bfdDiagnostic>
      <echoFunctionFailedCount>0</echoFunctionFailedCount>
      <noDiagnosticCount>1</noDiagnosticCount>
      <pathDownCount>0</pathDownCount>
      <administrativelyDownCount>0</administrativelyDownCount>
      <controlDetectionTimeExpiredCount>0</controlDetectionTimeExpiredCount>
      <forwardingPlaneResetCount>0</forwardingPlaneResetCount>
      <reverseConcatenatedPathDownCount>0</reverseConcatenatedPathDownCount>
      <neighborSignaledSessionDownCount>0</neighborSignaledSessionDownCount>
      <concatenatedPathDownCount>0</concatenatedPathDownCount>
    </bfdDiagnostic>
  </tunnelStatus>
</hostStatus>

Secured by basic

hostIdTunnelStatus /{hostId}/tunnel get

Working with tunnel connections for a specific host

get

Retrieve tunnel connections for a specific host. Tunnel details are retrieved for a maximum of 1560 tunnels on the host.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.

get hostIdTunnelStatus /2.0/vdn/host/{hostId}/tunnel

Retrieve tunnel connections for a specific host. Tunnel details are retrieved for a maximum of 1560 tunnels on the host.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • hostId: required (string)

    ID of the host.

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<bfdTunnels>
  <tunnel>
    <localIp>192.168.250.101</localIp>
    <bfd>
      <remoteState>DOWN</remoteState>
      <remoteDiagnostic>CONTROL_DETECTION_TIME_EXPIRED</remoteDiagnostic>
      <active>true</active>
      <state>INIT</state>
      <forwarding>false</forwarding>
      <diagnostic>NEIGHBOR_SIGNALED_SESSION_DOWN</diagnostic>
    </bfd>
    <remoteIp>192.168.250.100</remoteIp>
    <egressInterface>vmk10</egressInterface>
    <name>stt3232299620</name>
    <encap>VXLAN</encap>
    <status>DOWN</status>
    <remoteNodeId>host-31</remoteNodeId>
  </tunnel>
</bfdTunnels>

Secured by basic

hostIdRemoteHostStatus /{hostId}/remote-host-status get

Working with remote host status

get

Retrieve status of all remote hosts with tunnel connections to the given host.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.

get hostIdRemoteHostStatus /2.0/vdn/host/{hostId}/remote-host-status

Retrieve status of all remote hosts with tunnel connections to the given host.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • hostId: required (string)

    ID of the host.

Query Parameters

  • source: (string)

    Specify source as REALTIME, or CACHED. Default value is CACHED. Use status?source=REALTIME to get current status. Use status?source=CACHED to get cached status.

  • tunnel_status: (string)

    Specify UP, DOWN, or DEGRADED to filter by tunnel status. Default value is NONE.

  • bfd_diagnostic_code: (string)

    This field is used to filter the remote hosts in current host’s tunnel status detail list by the remoteDiagnostic field, for the tunnel status detail list. BFD diagnostic code of tunnel is as defined in RFC 5880. Allowed values are: NO_DIAGNOSTIC, CONTROL_DETECTION_TIME_EXPIRED, ECHO_FUNCTION_FAILED, NEIGHBOR_SIGNALED_SESSION_DOWN, FORWARDING_PLANE_RESET, PATH_DOWN, CONCATENATED_PATH_DOWN, ADMINISTRATIVELY_DOWN, REVERSE_CONCATENATED_PATH_DOWN.

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<bfdTunnels>
  <tunnel>
    <localIp>192.168.250.101</localIp>
    <bfd>
      <remoteState>DOWN</remoteState>
      <remoteDiagnostic>CONTROL_DETECTION_TIME_EXPIRED</remoteDiagnostic>
      <active>true</active>
      <state>INIT</state>
      <forwarding>false</forwarding>
      <diagnostic>NEIGHBOR_SIGNALED_SESSION_DOWN</diagnostic>
    </bfd>
    <remoteIp>192.168.250.100</remoteIp>
    <egressInterface>vmk10</egressInterface>
    <name>stt3232299620</name>
    <encap>VXLAN</encap>
    <status>DOWN</status>
    <remoteNodeId>host-31</remoteNodeId>
  </tunnel>
</bfdTunnels>

Secured by basic

bfdConfig

Working With BFD Global Configuration

You can enable or disable BFD to monitor hypervisor tunnel health statistics including tunnel latency. By default, BFD is disabled.

BFD Parameters

ParameterDescriptionComments
enabledEnable or disable BFD to monitor hypervisor tunnel health statistics including tunnel latency.Required. Options are True or False. Default is False.
pollingIntervalSecondsForHostConfigure the BFD polling interval.Optional. Value should be greater than 30. Default value is 180.
bfdIntervalMillSecondsForHostConfigure the interval of BFD session in milliseconds.Optional. Value should be greater than 300. Default value is 120000.

bfdConfig /2.0/vdn/bfd/configuration/global get put

get

Retrieve the BFD global configuration.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.
put

Update the BFD global configuration.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.

get bfdConfig /2.0/vdn/bfd/configuration/global

Retrieve the BFD global configuration.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<bfdGlobalConfiguration>
  <enabled>false</enabled>
  <pollingIntervalSecondsForHost>180</pollingIntervalSecondsForHost>
  <bfdIntervalMillSecondsForHost>120000</bfdIntervalMillSecondsForHost>
</bfdGlobalConfiguration>

Secured by basic

put bfdConfig /2.0/vdn/bfd/configuration/global

Update the BFD global configuration.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.4.0Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Response
  • Security

HTTP status code 200

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<bfdGlobalConfiguration>
  <enabled>true</enabled>
  <pollingIntervalSecondsForHost>190</pollingIntervalSecondsForHost>
  <bfdIntervalMillSecondsForHost>300</bfdIntervalMillSecondsForHost>
</bfdGlobalConfiguration>

Secured by basic

pnicCheckConfig

Working With pNIC Configuration Information

Provides the status information about physical NIC (pNIC) global configuration. You can enable or disable pNIC to monitor tunnel health of a hypervisor. By default, pNIC is disabled.

pNIC Parameters

ParameterDescriptionComments
enabledEnable or disable pNIC to monitor tunnel health of a hypervisor.Required. Options are True or False. Default is False.
pollingIntervalSecondsForHostConfigure the pNIC polling interval for the host.Required. Value should be greater than 30. Default value is 180.

servicesApps

Working With Services Grouping Objects

servicesAppsScopeScope /scope/{scopeId} get

Retrieve Services from a Specific Scope

get

Retrieve services that have been created on the specified scope.

get servicesAppsScopeScope /2.0/services/application/scope/{scopeId}

Retrieve services that have been created on the specified scope.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • scopeId: required (string)

    Can be globalroot-0, universalroot-0 or datacenterId in upgrade use cases.

Secured by basic

servicesAppsScope /{scopeId} post

Create a Service on a Specific Scope

post

Create a new service on the specified scope.

post servicesAppsScope /2.0/services/application/{scopeId}

Create a new service on the specified scope.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • scopeId: required (string)

Body

Type: application/xml

Schema:

<xs:schema attributeFormDefault="unqualified" elementFormDefault="qualified" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">
  <xs:element name="application">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="objectId"/>
        <xs:element name="type">
          <xs:complexType>
            <xs:sequence>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="typeName"/>
            </xs:sequence>
          </xs:complexType>
        </xs:element>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="description"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="name"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:byte" name="revision"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="objectTypeName"/>
        <xs:element name="element">
          <xs:complexType>
            <xs:sequence>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="applicationProtocol"/>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="value"/>
            </xs:sequence>
          </xs:complexType>
        </xs:element>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>
</xs:schema>

Example:

<application>
  <revision>0</revision>
  <name>TestService</name>
  <clientHandle></clientHandle>
  <isUniversal>false</isUniversal>
  <universalRevision>0</universalRevision>
  <inheritanceAllowed>true</inheritanceAllowed>
  <element>
    <applicationProtocol>MS_RPC_TCP</applicationProtocol>
    <value>420</value>
  </element>
</application>

Secured by basic

serviceApp /{applicationId} get put delete

Working With a Specified Service

get

Retrieve details about the specified service.

put

Modify the name, description, applicationProtocol, or port value of a service.

delete

Delete the specified service.

get serviceApp /2.0/services/application/{applicationId}

Retrieve details about the specified service.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • applicationId: required (string)

    Application ID. You can get a list of application IDs from GET /api/2.0/services/application/scope/{scopeId}.

Secured by basic

put serviceApp /2.0/services/application/{applicationId}

Modify the name, description, applicationProtocol, or port value of a service.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • applicationId: required (string)

    Application ID. You can get a list of application IDs from GET /api/2.0/services/application/scope/{scopeId}.

Body

Type: application/xml

Schema:

<xs:schema attributeFormDefault="unqualified" elementFormDefault="qualified" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">
  <xs:element name="application">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="objectId"/>
        <xs:element name="type">
          <xs:complexType>
            <xs:sequence>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="typeName"/>
            </xs:sequence>
          </xs:complexType>
        </xs:element>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="description"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="name"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="revision"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="objectTypeName"/>
        <xs:element name="element">
          <xs:complexType>
            <xs:sequence>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="applicationProtocol"/>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="value"/>
            </xs:sequence>
          </xs:complexType>
        </xs:element>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>
</xs:schema>

Example:

<application>
  <objectId>application-371</objectId>
  <objectTypeName>Application</objectTypeName>
  <vsmUuid>422A532F-41FA-4388-AC80-12F967B51339</vsmUuid>
  <nodeId>8fd64272-b735-44b8-8b93-525a00a82d5d</nodeId>
  <revision>2</revision>
  <type>
      <typeName>Application</typeName>
  </type>
  <name>TestService-Renamed</name>
  <scope>
      <id>globalroot-0</id>
      <objectTypeName>GlobalRoot</objectTypeName>
      <name>Global</name>
  </scope>
  <clientHandle></clientHandle>
  <extendedAttributes/>
  <isUniversal>false</isUniversal>
  <universalRevision>0</universalRevision>
  <inheritanceAllowed>true</inheritanceAllowed>
  <element>
      <applicationProtocol>MS_RPC_UDP</applicationProtocol>
      <value>500</value>
  </element>
</application>

Secured by basic

delete serviceApp /2.0/services/application/{applicationId}

Delete the specified service.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • applicationId: required (string)

    Application ID. You can get a list of application IDs from GET /api/2.0/services/application/scope/{scopeId}.

Query Parameters

  • force: (boolean)

    Determines if the delete should be forced or unforced. Default is false.

    If true, the object is deleted even if it is in use in other places such as firewall rules, which invalidates other configurations referring to the deleted object.

    If false, the object is deleted only if it is not being used by any other configuration.

Secured by basic

applicationgroup

Working With Service Groups Grouping Objects

serviceGroups /{scopeId} post

Creating Service Groups on a Specific Scope

post

Create a new service group on the specified scope.

post serviceGroups /2.0/services/applicationgroup/{scopeId}

Create a new service group on the specified scope.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • scopeId: required (string)

    The scopeId can be globalroot-0, universalroot-0 or datacenterId in upgrade use cases.

Body

Type: application/xml

Schema:

<xs:schema attributeFormDefault="unqualified" elementFormDefault="qualified" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">
  <xs:element name="applicationGroup">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="description"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="name"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="revision"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="inheritanceAllowed"/>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>
</xs:schema>

Example:

<applicationGroup>
  <description></description>
  <name></name>
  <revision></revision>
  <inheritanceAllowed></inheritanceAllowed>
</applicationGroup>

  • Security

    The scopeId can be globalroot-0, universalroot-0 or datacenterId in upgrade use cases.

serviceGroup /{applicationgroupId} get put delete

Working With a Specific Service Group

get

Retrieve details about the specified service group.

put

Modify the name, description, applicationProtocol, or port value of the specified service group.

delete

Delete the specified service group (application group) from a scope.

get serviceGroup /2.0/services/applicationgroup/{applicationgroupId}

Retrieve details about the specified service group.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • applicationgroupId: required (string)

    Application group ID

Secured by basic

put serviceGroup /2.0/services/applicationgroup/{applicationgroupId}

Modify the name, description, applicationProtocol, or port value of the specified service group.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • applicationgroupId: required (string)

    Application group ID

Body

Type: application/xml

Schema:

<xs:schema attributeFormDefault="unqualified" elementFormDefault="qualified" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">
  <xs:element name="applicationGroup">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="objectId"/>
        <xs:element name="type">
          <xs:complexType>
            <xs:sequence>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="typeName"/>
            </xs:sequence>
          </xs:complexType>
        </xs:element>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="name"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="description"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="revision"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="objectTypeName"/>
        <xs:element name="scope">
          <xs:complexType>
            <xs:sequence>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="id"/>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="objectTypeName"/>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="name"/>
            </xs:sequence>
          </xs:complexType>
        </xs:element>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="extendedAttributes"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="inheritanceAllowed"/>
        <xs:element name="member">
          <xs:complexType>
            <xs:sequence>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="objectId"/>
              <xs:element name="type">
                <xs:complexType>
                  <xs:sequence>
                    <xs:element type="xs:string" name="typeName"/>
                  </xs:sequence>
                </xs:complexType>
              </xs:element>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="name"/>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="revision"/>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="objectTypeName"/>
              <xs:element name="scope">
                <xs:complexType>
                  <xs:sequence>
                    <xs:element type="xs:string" name="id"/>
                    <xs:element type="xs:string" name="objectTypeName"/>
                    <xs:element type="xs:string" name="name"/>
                  </xs:sequence>
                </xs:complexType>
              </xs:element>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="extendedAttributes"/>
            </xs:sequence>
          </xs:complexType>
        </xs:element>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>
</xs:schema>

Example:

<applicationGroup>
  <objectId></objectId>
  <type>
    <typeName></typeName>
  </type>
  <name></name>
  <description></description>
  <revision></revision>
  <objectTypeName></objectTypeName>
  <scope>
    <id></id>
    <objectTypeName></objectTypeName>
    <name></name>
  </scope>
  <extendedAttributes></extendedAttributes>
  <inheritanceAllowed></inheritanceAllowed>
  <member>
    <objectId></objectId>
    <type>
      <typeName></typeName>
    </type>
    <name></name>
    <revision></revision>
    <objectTypeName></objectTypeName>
    <scope>
      <id></id>
      <objectTypeName></objectTypeName>
      <name></name>
    </scope>
  </member>
</applicationGroup>

Secured by basic

delete serviceGroup /2.0/services/applicationgroup/{applicationgroupId}

Delete the specified service group (application group) from a scope.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • applicationgroupId: required (string)

    Application group ID

Query Parameters

  • force: (boolean)

    Determines if the delete should be forced or unforced. Default is false.

    If true, the object is deleted even if it is in use in other places such as firewall rules, which invalidates other configurations referring to the deleted object.

    If false, the object is deleted only if it is not being used by any other configuration.

Secured by basic

serviceGroupMembers /members/{moref} put delete

Working With a Specific Service Group Member

put

Add a member to the service group.

delete

Delete a member from the service group.

put serviceGroupMembers /2.0/services/applicationgroup/{applicationgroupId}/members/{moref}

Add a member to the service group.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • applicationgroupId: required (string)

    Application group ID

  • moref: required (string)

    Managed object reference to the member.

Secured by basic

delete serviceGroupMembers /2.0/services/applicationgroup/{applicationgroupId}/members/{moref}

Delete a member from the service group.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • applicationgroupId: required (string)

    Application group ID

  • moref: required (string)

    Managed object reference to the member.

Secured by basic

serviceGroupMembersScope /scope/{scopeId}/members get

get

get serviceGroupMembersScope /2.0/services/applicationgroup/scope/{scopeId}/members

Get a list of member elements that can be added to the service groups created on a particular scope.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • scopeId: required (string)

    globalroot-0 or datacenterId in upgrade use cases

Secured by basic

ipPoolsObjects

Working With IP Pool Grouping Objects

ipPools /scope/{scopeId} get post

Working With IP Pools on a Specific Scope

get

Retrieves all IP pools on the specified scope where the scopeId is the reference to the desired scope. An example of the scopeID is globalroot-0.

post

Create a pool of IP addresses. For scopeId use globalroot-0 or the datacenterId in upgrade use cases.

get ipPools /2.0/services/ipam/pools/scope/{scopeId}

Retrieves all IP pools on the specified scope where the scopeId is the reference to the desired scope. An example of the scopeID is globalroot-0.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Response
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • scopeId: required (string)

    For scopeId use globalroot-0 or datacenterId in upgrade use cases.

HTTP status code 200

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<ipamAddressPool>
  <objectId>ipaddresspool-1</objectId>
  <objectTypeName>IpAddressPool</objectTypeName>
  <vsmUuid>4237BA90-C373-A71A-9827-1673BFA29498</vsmUuid>
  <revision>1</revision>
  <type>
    <typeName>IpAddressPool</typeName>
  </type>
  <name>rest-ip-pool-1</name>
  <extendedAttributes></extendedAttributes>
  <prefixLength>23</prefixLength>
  <gateway>192.168.1.1</gateway>
  <dnsSuffix>example.com</dnsSuffix>
  <dnsServer1>10.11.0.1</dnsServer1>
  <dnsServer2>10.11.0.2</dnsServer2>
  <ipRanges>
    <ipRangeDto>
      <id>iprange-1</id>
      <startAddress>192.168.1.2</startAddress>
      <endAddress>192.168.1.3</endAddress>
    </ipRangeDto>
  </ipRanges>
  <totalAddressCount>2</totalAddressCount>
  <usedAddressCount>0</usedAddressCount>
  <usedPercentage>0</usedPercentage>
</ipamAddressPool>

Secured by basic

post ipPools /2.0/services/ipam/pools/scope/{scopeId}

Create a pool of IP addresses. For scopeId use globalroot-0 or the datacenterId in upgrade use cases.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • scopeId: required (string)

    For scopeId use globalroot-0 or datacenterId in upgrade use cases.

Body

Type: application/xml

Schema:

<xs:schema attributeFormDefault="unqualified" elementFormDefault="qualified" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">
  <xs:element name="ipamAddressPool">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="name"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="prefixLength"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="gateway"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="dnsSuffix"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="dnsServer1"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="dnsServer2"/>
        <xs:element name="ipRanges">
          <xs:complexType>
            <xs:sequence>
              <xs:element name="ipRangeDto">
                <xs:complexType>
                  <xs:sequence>
                    <xs:element type="xs:string" name="startAddress"/>
                    <xs:element type="xs:string" name="endAddress"/>
                  </xs:sequence>
                </xs:complexType>
              </xs:element>
            </xs:sequence>
          </xs:complexType>
        </xs:element>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>
</xs:schema>

Example:

<ipamAddressPool>
  <name></name>
  <prefixLength></prefixLength>
  <gateway></gateway>
  <dnsSuffix></dnsSuffix>
  <dnsServer1></dnsServer1>
  <dnsServer2></dnsServer2>
  <ipRanges>
    <ipRangeDto>
      <startAddress></startAddress>
      <endAddress></endAddress>
    </ipRangeDto>
  </ipRanges>
</ipamAddressPool>

Secured by basic

ipPool /{poolId} get put delete

get

put

To modify an IP pool, query the IP pool first. Then modify the output and send it back as the request body.

delete

get ipPool /2.0/services/ipam/pools/{poolId}

  • Request
  • Response
  • Security

  • poolId: required (string)

    Specify the pool ID as poolId in the URI.

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<ipamAddressPool>
  <objectId>ipaddresspool-1</objectId>
  <objectTypeName>IpAddressPool</objectTypeName>

  <revision>1</revision>
  <type>
    <typeName>IpAddressPool</typeName>
  </type>

  <usedAddressCount>0</usedAddressCount>

  • Security

  • poolId: required (string)

    Specify the pool ID as poolId in the URI.

Type: application/xml

Schema:

<xs:schema attributeFormDefault="unqualified" elementFormDefault="qualified" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">
  <xs:element name="ipamAddressPool">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="objectId"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="objectTypeName"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="vsmUuid"/>

            </xs:sequence>

        </xs:element>

                  <xs:sequence>
                    <xs:element type="xs:string" name="id"/>
                    <xs:element type="xs:string" name="startAddress"/>
                    <xs:element type="xs:string" name="endAddress"/>
                  </xs:sequence>
                </xs:complexType>
              </xs:element>
            </xs:sequence>
          </xs:complexType>
        </xs:element>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>
</xs:schema>

ipPoolAllocate /ipaddresses get post

Working With IP Pool Address Allocations

get

Retrieves all allocated IP addresses from the specified pool.

post

Allocate an IP address from the pool.

To allocate the next available IP, set allocationMode to ALLOCATE

<ipAddressRequest>
  <allocationMode>ALLOCATE</allocationMode>
</ipAddressRequest>

To allocate a specific IP, set allocationMode to RESERVE and pass the IP to reserve in the ipAddress parameter.

<ipAddressRequest>
  <allocationMode>RESERVE</allocationMode>
  <ipAddress>192.168.1.2</ipAddress>
</ipAddressRequest>

get ipPoolAllocate /2.0/services/ipam/pools/{poolId}/ipaddresses

Retrieves all allocated IP addresses from the specified pool.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Response
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • poolId: required (string)

    Specify the pool ID as poolId in the URI.

HTTP status code 200

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<allocatedIpAddresses>
  <allocatedIpAddress>
    <id>allocatedipaddress-4</id>
    <ipAddress>192.168.1.2</ipAddress>
    <gateway>192.168.1.1</gateway>
    <prefixLength>23</prefixLength>
    <dnsServer1>10.112.0.1</dnsServer1>
    <dnsServer2>10.112.0.2</dnsServer2>
    <dnsSuffix>eng.vmware.com</dnsSuffix>
    <allocationNote>sample note</allocationNote>
  </allocatedIpAddress>
</allocatedIpAddresses>

Secured by basic

post ipPoolAllocate /2.0/services/ipam/pools/{poolId}/ipaddresses

Allocate an IP address from the pool.

To allocate the next available IP, set allocationMode to ALLOCATE

<ipAddressRequest>
  <allocationMode>ALLOCATE</allocationMode>
</ipAddressRequest>

To allocate a specific IP, set allocationMode to RESERVE and pass the IP to reserve in the ipAddress parameter.

<ipAddressRequest>
  <allocationMode>RESERVE</allocationMode>
  <ipAddress>192.168.1.2</ipAddress>
</ipAddressRequest>
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Response
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • poolId: required (string)

    Specify the pool ID as poolId in the URI.

Body

Type: application/xml

Schema:

<xs:schema attributeFormDefault="unqualified" elementFormDefault="qualified" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">
  <xs:element name="ipAddressRequest">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="allocationMode"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="ipAddress"/>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>
</xs:schema>

Example:

<ipAddressRequest>
  <allocationMode>RESERVE</allocationMode>
  <ipAddress>192.168.1.2</ipAddress>
</ipAddressRequest>

HTTP status code 200

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<allocatedIpAddress>
  <id>allocatedipaddress-1</id>
  <ipAddress>192.168.1.2</ipAddress>
  <gateway>192.168.1.1</gateway>
  <prefixLength>23</prefixLength>
  <dnsServer1>10.112.0.1</dnsServer1>
  <dnsServer2>10.112.0.2</dnsServer2>
  <dnsSuffix>eng.vmware.com</dnsSuffix>
  <allocationNote>sample note</allocationNote>
</allocatedIpAddress>

Secured by basic

ipAddressRelease /{ipAddress} delete

delete

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • poolId: required (string)

    Specify the pool ID as poolId in the URI.

  • ipAddress: required (string)

    The IP address to release, e.g. 192.168.10.10.

Secured by basic

nsxLicensing

Working With Licensing

The licensing capacity usage API command reports usage of CPUs, VMs and concurrent users for the distributed firewall and VXLAN. The licensing status API command displays details about the assigned license.

capacityUsage /capacityusage get

Working With Licensing Capacity

The licensing capacity usage API command reports usage of CPUs, VMs and concurrent users for the distributed firewall and VXLAN.

get

Retrieve capacity usage information on the usage of CPUs, VMs and concurrent users for the distributed firewall and VXLAN.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.2.3Method introduced.

get capacityUsage /2.0/services/licensing/capacityusage

Retrieve capacity usage information on the usage of CPUs, VMs and concurrent users for the distributed firewall and VXLAN.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.2.3Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Response
  • Security

HTTP status code 200

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<featureCapacityUsageList>
  <featureCapacityUsageInfo>
    <capacityUsageInfo>
      <capacityType>CPU_CAPACITY_TYPE</capacityType>
      <usageCount>16</usageCount>
    </capacityUsageInfo>
    <capacityUsageInfo>
      <capacityType>VM_CAPACITY_TYPE</capacityType>
      <usageCount>3</usageCount>
    </capacityUsageInfo>
    <capacityUsageInfo>
      <capacityType>CONCURRENT_USER_CAPACITY_TYPE</capacityType>
      <usageCount>3</usageCount>
    </capacityUsageInfo>
    <feature>dfw</feature>
  </featureCapacityUsageInfo>
  <featureCapacityUsageInfo>
    <capacityUsageInfo>
      <capacityType>CPU_CAPACITY_TYPE</capacityType>
      <usageCount>16</usageCount>
    </capacityUsageInfo>
    <capacityUsageInfo>
      <capacityType>VM_CAPACITY_TYPE</capacityType>
      <usageCount>3</usageCount>
    </capacityUsageInfo>
    <capacityUsageInfo>
      <capacityType>CONCURRENT_USER_CAPACITY_TYPE</capacityType>
      <usageCount>3</usageCount>
    </capacityUsageInfo>
    <feature>vxlan</feature>
  </featureCapacityUsageInfo>
</featureCapacityUsageList>

securitytags

Working With Security Tags

You can manage security tags and their virtual machine assignments. For example, you can create a user defined security tag, assign tags to a virtual machine, view tags assigned to virtual machines, and view virtual machines that have a specific tag assigned.

securitytagsTag /tag post get

Managing Security Tags

post

Create a new security tag.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.3.0Method updated. isUniversal parameter can be set to create a universal security tag.
get

Retrieve all security tags.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.3.0Method updated. Added isUniversal query parameter to filter universal security tags.
6.3.3Method updated. Output is now paginated. startIndex, pageSize, sortOrderAscending, sortBy, filterBy, and filterValue query parameters added.

post securitytagsTag /2.0/services/securitytags/tag

Create a new security tag.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.3.0Method updated. isUniversal parameter can be set to create a universal security tag.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

Body

Type: application/xml

Schema:

<xs:schema attributeFormDefault="unqualified" elementFormDefault="qualified" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">
  <xs:element name="securityTag">
    <xs:complexType>
      <xs:sequence>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="objectTypeName"/>
        <xs:element name="type">
          <xs:complexType>
            <xs:sequence>
              <xs:element type="xs:string" name="typeName"/>
            </xs:sequence>
          </xs:complexType>
        </xs:element>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="name"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:boolean" name="isUniversal"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="description"/>
        <xs:element type="xs:string" name="extendedAttributes"/>
      </xs:sequence>
    </xs:complexType>
  </xs:element>
</xs:schema>

Example:

<securityTag>
  <objectTypeName>SecurityTag</objectTypeName>
  <type>
    <typeName>SecurityTag</typeName>
  </type>
  <name>TAG_NAME</name>
  <isUniversal>true</isUniversal>
  <description>description of the tag</description>
  <extendedAttributes></extendedAttributes>
</securityTag>

Secured by basic

get securitytagsTag /2.0/services/securitytags/tag

Retrieve all security tags.

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.3.0Method updated. Added isUniversal query parameter to filter universal security tags.
6.3.3Method updated. Output is now paginated. startIndex, pageSize, sortOrderAscending, sortBy, filterBy, and filterValue query parameters added.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Response
  • Security

Query Parameters

  • isUniversal: (boolean)

    Set to true to view universal security tags only. Set to false to view security tags local to that NSX Manager only. To view all tags (tags local to that NSX Manager plus universal tags), omit the action parameter.

  • startIndex: (string)

    The starting point for returning results.

  • pageSize: (string)

    The number of results to return. Default is 1024.

  • sortOrderAscending: (string)

    Sort in ascending order of start time (true or false).

  • sortBy: (string)

    Parameter to sort by. Default is objectId.

  • filterBy: (string)

    Parameter type to filter by. Options are objectId or name.

  • filterValue: (string)

    Value for filterBy. For example, securitytag-1 if filterBy is objectId, or IDS_IPS.threat=medium if filterBy is name.

HTTP status code 200

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<securityTags>
  <pagingInfo>
    <pageSize>1024</pageSize>
    <startIndex>0</startIndex>
    <totalCount>2</totalCount>
    <sortOrderAscending>true</sortOrderAscending>
    <sortBy>objectId</sortBy>
  </pagingInfo>
  <securityTag>
    <objectId>securitytag-1</objectId>
    <objectTypeName>SecurityTag</objectTypeName>
    <vsmUuid>42030D04-DA84-841C-B02B-3D0F845AF88A</vsmUuid>
    <nodeId>6438f0c2-593c-4237-b116-7c958fffa15b</nodeId>
    <revision>0</revision>
    <type>
      <typeName>SecurityTag</typeName>
    </type>
    <name>VULNERABILITY_MGMT.VulnerabilityFound.threat=high</name>
    <description>Tag indicates that the vulnerability found has a high threat level</description>
    <clientHandle></clientHandle>
    <extendedAttributes/>
    <isUniversal>false</isUniversal>
    <universalRevision>0</universalRevision>
    <systemResource>true</systemResource>
    <vmCount>0</vmCount>
  </securityTag>
  <securityTag>
    <objectId>securitytag-10</objectId>
    <objectTypeName>SecurityTag</objectTypeName>
    <vsmUuid>42030D04-DA84-841C-B02B-3D0F845AF88A</vsmUuid>
    <nodeId>6438f0c2-593c-4237-b116-7c958fffa15b</nodeId>
    <revision>0</revision>
    <type>
      <typeName>SecurityTag</typeName>
    </type>
    <name>IDS_IPS.threat=medium</name>
    <description>Tag indicates that the data violation detected has a medium threat level</description>
    <clientHandle></clientHandle>
    <extendedAttributes/>
    <isUniversal>false</isUniversal>
    <universalRevision>0</universalRevision>
    <systemResource>true</systemResource>
    <vmCount>0</vmCount>
  </securityTag>
</securityTags>

Secured by basic

securityTagDelete /{tagId} delete

Delete a Security Tag

delete

Delete the specified security tag.

delete securityTagDelete /2.0/services/securitytags/tag/{tagId}

Delete the specified security tag.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • tagId: required (string)

    Specified security tag.

Query Parameters

  • force: (string)

    When the tag is in use and you want to delete the tag, provide ?force=true in the API.

Secured by basic

securityTagVMsList /vm get post

Working With Virtual Machines on a Specific Security Tag

get

Retrieve the list of VMs that have the specified tag attached to them.

post

Attach or detach a security tag to a virtual machine.

This operation does not check that the virtual machine exists in the local inventory. This allows you to attach a universal security tag to a virtual machine that is connected to a secondary NSX Manager (and therefore is not connected to the primary NSX Manager where the call is sent).

Possible keys for the tagParameter are:

  • instance_uuid
  • bios_uuid
  • vmname

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.3.0Method introduced.

get securityTagVMsList /2.0/services/securitytags/tag/{tagId}/vm

Retrieve the list of VMs that have the specified tag attached to them.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • tagId: required (string)

    Specified security tag.

Secured by basic

post securityTagVMsList /2.0/services/securitytags/tag/{tagId}/vm

Attach or detach a security tag to a virtual machine.

This operation does not check that the virtual machine exists in the local inventory. This allows you to attach a universal security tag to a virtual machine that is connected to a secondary NSX Manager (and therefore is not connected to the primary NSX Manager where the call is sent).

Possible keys for the tagParameter are:

  • instance_uuid
  • bios_uuid
  • vmname

Method history:

ReleaseModification
6.3.0Method introduced.
Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • tagId: required (string)

    Specified security tag.

Query Parameters

  • action: required (string)

    Action to perform: attach or detach specified security tag from the VMs listed in the request body.

Body

Type: application/xml

Example:

<securityTagAssignment>
  <tagParameter>
   <key>instance_uuid</key>
   <value>123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426655440000</value>
  </tagParameter>
</securityTagAssignment>

Secured by basic

securityTagVM /{vmId} put delete

Manage a Security Tag on a Virtual Machine

put

Apply a security tag to the specified virtual machine.

Note: this method can attach a universal security tag to a virtual machine. However, this method checks that the VM exists on the NSX Manager to which the API call is sent. In a cross-vCenter active active environment, the VM might exist on a secondary NSX Manager, and so the call would fail.

You can instead use the POST /api/2.0/services/securitytags/tag/{tagId}/vm?action=attach method to attach universal security tags to a VM that is not local to the primary NSX Manager. This method does not check that the VM is local to the NSX Manager.

delete

Detach a security tag from the specified virtual machine.

put securityTagVM /2.0/services/securitytags/tag/{tagId}/vm/{vmId}

Apply a security tag to the specified virtual machine.

Note: this method can attach a universal security tag to a virtual machine. However, this method checks that the VM exists on the NSX Manager to which the API call is sent. In a cross-vCenter active active environment, the VM might exist on a secondary NSX Manager, and so the call would fail.

You can instead use the POST /api/2.0/services/securitytags/tag/{tagId}/vm?action=attach method to attach universal security tags to a VM that is not local to the primary NSX Manager. This method does not check that the VM is local to the NSX Manager.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • tagId: required (string)

    Specified security tag.

  • vmId: required (string)

    Specify VM using VM managed object ID or VM instance UUID.

Secured by basic

delete securityTagVM /2.0/services/securitytags/tag/{tagId}/vm/{vmId}

Detach a security tag from the specified virtual machine.

Secured by basic
  • Request
  • Security

URI Parameters

  • tagId: required (string)

    Specified security tag.

  • vmId: required (string)

    Specify VM using VM managed object ID or VM instance UUID.

Secured by basic
